lexUnit.name: postpone.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: arrange for (something) to take place at a time later than that first scheduled.

sentence.text: Britain doubted whether the UN could do more than to postpone the day when Soviet domination over Korea was established .
Permitting new supplies , as is suggested in paragraph 55 of draft MPG6 , only postpones the day when such a prospect has to be faced .
The Rolling Stones , George Harrison , Bob Dylan and Rod Stewart are still strutting and fretting away , postponing the time when they are heard no more .
It is impossible to postpone childbearing indefinitely without children being cancelled altogether .
He postponed implementing a scheme until more groups , including industry and business , were consulted .
The judge postponed sentencing for pyschiatric reports but warned the normal punishment for attempted robbery was at least 7 years in prison .
The Mexican government has postponed plans to construct a hydro-electric dam on the Rio Usumancinta , near the border with Guatemala .
There was also concern among US officials that the funding would encourage Israel to continue to postpone steps to liberalize the economy .
With an election looming on June 6th , the Socialist government had every reason to postpone the embarrassment of a third successive devaluation .
The banks also agreed to postpone amortization payments due between 1991 and 1994 , a measure calculated to save Chile approximately $1,800 million annually over the following four years .
Television had postponed Manchester United 's scheduled visit to Anfield so it could be shown live on 22 December , the longest night .
It does not seem , in general , valuable to postpone death by a few hours at enormous cost .
As things are , I 'd like you to postpone your leave for a bit . "
The mother postponed her second marriage for six months to give time to sort out the new relationships .
When the Soviet parliament invoked emergency laws to postpone the strike for two months , the union refused to call it off -- in effect , daring the government to end it by force .

Tripoli postponed the elections until February ; Ajdabiyans confidently expected them on 1 February , and after that day the chairman of the local Assembly telephoned Tripoli each afternoon to ask if he should hold the poll .
The Law Society has urged the Government to postpone the changes in civil legal aid for one year because it believes the rise in spending on it is a temporary blip .
He plans to go ahead with his wedding , which was postponed last Wednesday , on his return to Sarajevo .
Originally scheduled for late May , the conference was postponed by the government to July 15 .
However , the trial has been postponed indefinitely .
The presentation of the 1991/92 budget had been postponed from February 1991 under Congress ( I ) pressure because of the approaching general election [ see p. 38006 ] .
The freeing of oil prices was postponed until June from the target date of April 1 .
The danger is that prospective purchasers will postpone spending money until they have finished upgrading to Windows .
John Scott Morgan , author and a member of the Society , had to postpone the talk originally arranged for October 1992 .
The visit , postponed from September , included an address by Yeltsin to the South Korean National Assembly on Nov. 19 .
The Presidents of Russia and Lithuania postponed until October the actual signature of a treaty on troop withdrawal , due to " technical " difficulties .
His wife Val contributes a postscript in which she reveals , rather wanly , that she is still looking forward to her honeymoon , postponed because of a rugby match .
We can stay much as we are , in the same old muddle , with difficult decisions postponed .
You avoid , postpone , or hide the conflict that you fear .
